awd_titl_txt: Seismic Signatures of Inner Core Solidification
awd_abstract_narration:
The deep interior of Earth, revealed by seismic waves, affects processes at the surface of our planet. Among these is the solidification of Earth's inner core from the liquid iron of its outer core. Variations in this solidification, detected from seismic waves, will be helpful in understanding and predicting variations in our magnetic field that can affect our atmosphere and surface life. This project seeks to map the solidification of Earth's inner core using seismic waves reflected and transmitted through it. Education and training will be provided to graduate students in computation, digital data retrieval and processing, and structural imaging from any wave-like phenomena.  These skills are transferable to broad areas of science and engineering, including resource exploration, computational science, and medical imaging. Results will be incorporated in undergraduate introductory courses to encourage recruitment and retention of students across STEM fields. Results will also be regularly shared with public media having interests in earthquakes and planetary science.

Transitions in the elastic structure beneath the Inner Core Boundary (ICB), including their effects on lateral variations in elastic waves speeds, body waveform complexity and attenuation and the depth onset of elastic anisotropy are important for understanding the process of compositional convection. This process has been favored as the mechanism that currently sustains our magnetic field through the crystallization and the buoyant rise of light elements as the inner core solidifies. Unique elements of the proposed activity include separating the effect of earthquake sources on waveforms to improve estimates of inner core attenuation, evaluating the relative contributions of attenuation by forward scattering and intrinsic attenuation, relating small- scale heterogeneity to a solidification fabric and elastic anisotropy, and exploiting the use of a body wave having high sensitivity to the shear velocity structure beneath the inner core boundary.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
Importance of problem

The arrival times and shapes of earthquake seismic waves transmitted through Earth?s solid iron inner core are sensitive to both its larger-scale temperature and pressure as well as much smaller-scale structures, on the order of 1-10 km, in size. The reduction in amplitudes of seismic waves transiting the Earth?s inner core due to mechanisms of friction and scattering reveals the process of its solidification from the liquid outer core.  This solidification drives the motion of liquid metallic, electrically conducting, iron in Earth?s outer that sustains its magnetic field.  The depth variations in this solidification, detected from seismic waves, are helpful in understanding the history and future of Earth?s magnetic field affecting our atmosphere and surface life.

Scientific results

This project measured the depth dependence of the solidification processes of Earth?s inner core using seismic waves reflected and transmitted through it.  From analyses of seismic waveforms we quantified the depth dependence of fluctuations of seismic wave velocities in the inner core, determining bounds on the size crystalline heterogeneities (less than 2%) and fluctuation of elastic compressional waves (less than 2% near the surface of the inner core decreasing to less than 0.5% its center). We separated the effects of scattering and internal friction on the seismic waves that sample the inner core, finding that internal friction dominates the width and height of the early part of waveforms, with scattering controlling the shape and complexity of the later part of the waveform.  Both scattering and internal friction decrease with depth in the inner core, with a sharp decrease in both effects occurring half-way to its center, signifying a change with time in the processes of its solidification as it freezes iron from the liquid outer core.

Impacts on other sciences

The seismic velocities and material textures determined in this project are correlated with other physical properties, including electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity, and magnetic and electric susceptibilities. Direct measurements of these physical properties are experimentally challenging and nearly impossible to achieve either experimentally or by theoretical computations at the temperature and pressure of planetary materials. This is especially true for multi-component materials, such as Earth?s core, undergoing a freezing or melting transition.  Constraints on physical properties obtained by seismology in this pressure and temperature regime can have unforeseen benefits to broader problems in material science.

Education and training

Education and training was provided to a graduate student and post-doctoral fellow in computation exploiting multi-core/multi-node processors, digital data retrieval and processing, and structural imaging from any wave-like phenomena.  These skills are transferable to broad areas of science and engineering, including resource exploration, computational science, and medical imaging. Instruction in observations and interpretations were incorporated in undergraduate introductory courses to encourage recruitment and retention of students across STEM fields.
